prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Factors articulated by the Panel in selecting transferee district—Overall docket conditions

para.paratext: The Panel has expressly stated that it will consider docket conditions in selecting a transferee district.[1] If two potential transferee districts have widely different docket conditions, one being relatively current and the other marked by long delays before trial, the Panel will favor the court with a current docket.[2] The Panel presumably considers this factor to some degree in every docket before it orders transfer. Minor differences in dockets have no impact on the decision.[3] It may express its views in terms of the docket itself or in a more general way.[4] The Panel may also take into consideration a potential transferee judge's view of docket conditions.[5]

Docket conditions are frequently not brought to the Panel's attention in an effective way. Although this is clearly a factor that the Panel will consider even if counsel do not raise it, it is frequently an important factor that should be considered and advanced by the attorneys for the parties. Statistical evidence of the condition of the dockets of the various potential transferee districts can be, and should be, made part of the record before the Panel. One effective way of doing this is to provide the Panel information from the most recent Annual Report of the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts. This information is useful to the Panel, and has been relied upon and cited by it.[6] Appendix B contains portions of the most recent report directly relevant to the Panel's considerations. The percentage of cases over three years old is an especially useful basis for comparing the various court dockets. The Panel has also indicated that the total caseload is not as significant to it as the median time to disposition.[7] The Panel has also considered statistical information showing the number of pending class actions and number of pending transferred multidistrict cases in determining the conditions of the docket in a potential transferee district.[8] Because the tables contained in Appendix B contain aggregate information for each district, it may be useful to make the data equivalent by calculating a “caseload per sitting judge” statistic if the potential transferee districts are of significantly different size. It may also be useful to obtain information concerning the docket of a potential transferee judge if that information is available from a calendar clerk.

A corollary concern of the Panel, though not articulated in its decisions, must be the capacity of the candidate transferee court and, particularly, of the Clerks' office in a transferee district to handle what may be an overwhelming burden of additional filings. This may relate to docket conditions in that the number of open files increases as backlogs increase, presumably the volume of filings is greater, and existing resources may be spread thinner. This concern tends to favor spreading out MDL transfers, particularly in mammoth matters,[9] it also tends to favor transfer to larger courts with larger Clerk's offices, at least for particularly large dockets. The Panel frequently expresses preference for a “metropolitan” district without saying more; the capacity of the Clerk's office is undoubtedly part of this preference.[10]

The Panel's concern for docket conditions is two-fold: it wants to transfer the actions to a district where the transferred actions can be efficiently and promptly handled and it wants to effect transfer without unduly disrupting the rights of other litigants to have their actions considered.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See, e.g., In re Wright Medical Technology, Inc., Conserve Hip Implant Products Liability Litigation, 844 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (J.P.M. L. 2012); In re Skechers Toning Shoe Products Liability Litigation, 831 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Transdata, Inc., Smart Meters Patent Litigation, 830 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Sony Gaming Networks and Customer Data Security Breach Litigation, 802 F. Supp. 2d 1370 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Teflon Products Liability Litigation, 416 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (J.P.M.L. 2006); In re Xyberbaut Corp. Securities Litigation, 403 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (favorable caseload statistics); In re Educational Testing Service PLT 7-12 Test Scoring Litigation, 350 F. Supp. 2d 1363 (J.P.M.L. 2004) (transfer to district with favorable caseload conditions); In re Corn Derivatives Antitrust Litigation, 486 F. Supp. 929, 931 (J.P.M.L. 1980); see also § 5:21, supra and cases cited.

See, e.g., In re: DePuy Orthopaedics, Inc., Pinnacle Hip Implant Products Liability Litigation, 787 F. Supp. 2d 1358 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2011); In re: Bank of America Wage and Hour Employment Practices Litigation, 706 F. Supp. 2d 1369, 1372 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2010) (noting docket conditions “considerably more favorable”); In re: Polar Bear Endangered Species Act Listing and 4(d) Rule Litigation, 588 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008); In re: Puerto Rican Cabotage Antitrust Litigation, 571 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Educational Testing Service PLT 7-12 Test Scoring Litigation, 350 F. Supp. 2d 1363 (J.P.M.L. 2004) (transfer to district with favorable caseload conditions); In re Corn Derivatives Antitrust Litigation, 486 F. Supp. 929, 931 (J.P.M.L. 1980); In re Air Crash Disaster at Taipei Intern. Airport on July 31, 1975, 433 F. Supp. 1120, 1121 (J.P.M.L. 1977); In re Preferential Drug Products Pricing Antitrust Litigation, 429 F. Supp. 1027, 1029 (J.P.M.L. 1977); In re Petroleum Products Antitrust Litigation, 419 F. Supp. 712, 719 (J.P.M.L. 1976); In re Eastern Airlines, Inc. Flight Attendant Weight Program Litigation, 391 F. Supp. 763, 765 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re Peruvian Road Litigation, 380 F. Supp. 796, 798 (J.P.M.L. 1974); In re Nat. Student Marketing Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 1311, 1318 (J.P.M.L. 1972); In re Transit Co. Tire Antitrust Litigation, 350 F. Supp. 1165, 1166 (J.P.M.L. 1972); In re Kauffman Mut. Fund Actions, 337 F. Supp. 1337, 1340 (J.P.M.L. 1972); In re Library Editions of Children's Books, 297 F. Supp. 385, 387 (J.P.M.L. 1968). See also In re Veeco Instruments Inc. Securities Litigation, 387 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (transfer to district with “more favorable caseload statistics”).

See In re Amtel, Inc. Securities Litigation, 447 F. Supp. 466, 468 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re Career Academy Antitrust Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 753 (J.P.M.L. 1972) (2- or 3–month difference insignificant).

See, e.g., In re E.I. du Pont de Nemours and Co. C-8 Personal Injury Litigation, 939 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2013) (transfer to less utilized district); In re Bextra and Celebrex Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 391 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (district “has capacity” to handle the litigation); In re Compression Labs, Inc., Patent Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (district equipped with resources); In re Paxil Products Liability Litigation, 296 F. Supp. 2d 1374, 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2003) (panel transfers to a “judge with the time and experience to steer this complex litigation on a prudent course”).
See, e.g., In re Ameriquest Mortg. Co. Mortg. Lending Practices Litigation, 408 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (J.P.M.L. 2005).

See, e.g., In re Corn Derivatives Antitrust Litigation, 486 F. Supp. 929, 931 (J.P.M.L. 1980); In re Air Crash Disaster at Taipei Intern. Airport on July 31, 1975, 433 F. Supp. 1120, 1121 (J.P.M.L. 1977); In re Preferential Drug Products Pricing Antitrust Litigation, 429 F. Supp. 1027, 1029 (J.P.M.L. 1977); In re Petroleum Products Antitrust Litigation, 419 F. Supp. 712, 719 (J.P.M.L. 1976); In re Eastern Airlines, Inc. Flight Attendant Weight Program Litigation, 391 F. Supp. 763, 765 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re Peruvian Road Litigation, 380 F. Supp. 796, 798 (J.P.M.L. 1974); In re Nat. Student Marketing Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 1311, 1318 (J.P.M.L. 1972); In re Transit Co. Tire Antitrust Litigation, 350 F. Supp. 1165, 1166 (J.P.M.L. 1972); In re Kauffman Mut. Fund Actions, 337 F. Supp. 1337, 1340 (J.P.M.L. 1972); In re Library Editions of Children's Books, 297 F. Supp. 385, 387 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
See In re Nat. Student Marketing Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 1311, 1318 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
See In re Corn Derivatives Antitrust Litigation, 486 F. Supp. 929, 931 (J.P.M.L. 1980).
See § 6:22, below, for discussion of this factor.

See, e.g., In re Pamidronate Products Liability Litigation, 657 F. Supp. 2d 1368 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Alfuzosin Hydrochloride Patent Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1372 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Trasylol Products Liability Litigation, 545 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Bluetooth Headset Products Liability Litigation, 475 F. Supp. 2d 1403 (J.P.M.L. 2007) (defendants and all responding plaintiffs support transfer motion); In re Webloyalty.com, Inc., Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 474 F. Supp. 2d 1353 (J.P.M.L. 2007); In re CertainTeed Corp. Roofing Shingle Products Liability Litigation, 474 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2007); In re Banc of America Inv. Services, Inc., 466 F. Supp. 2d 1353 (J.P.M.L. 2006); In re Jamster Marketing Litigation, 427 F. Supp. 2d 1366 (J.P.M.L. 2006); In re Guidant Corp. Implantable Defibrillators Products Liability Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re Rhodia S.A. Securities Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re LLRICE 601 Contamination Litigation, 466 F. Supp. 2d 1351 (J.P.M.L. 2006) (some plaintiffs and the common defendant favor district chosen by Panel); In re Circular Thermostat Antitrust Litigation, 370 F. Supp. 2d 1355 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re Insurance Brokerage Antitrust Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re Compression Labs, Inc., Patent Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2005). In re Gator Corp. Software Trademark & Copyright Litigation, 259 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re Educational Testing Service PLT 7-12 Test Scoring Litigation, 350 F. Supp. 2d 1363 (J.P.M.L. 2004) (accessible, metropolitan location with favorable caseload conditions); In re Metoprolol Succinate Patent Litigation, 329 F. Supp. 2d 1368 (J.P.M.L. 2004) (transfer to “accessible, metropolitan district”); In re Gator Corp. Software Trademark & Copyright Litigation, 259 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2003) (selection of accessible metropolitan court not currently overtaxed with multidistrict dockets and with sufficient resources).
